newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia anthrax area meat sales long halted.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia anthrax area meat sales long halted.

text.p: All Australian meat exports from the anthrax-affected area in the state of Victoria ceased on January 26 when the disease outbreak was discovered, statutory authority the Australian Meat and Livestock Corp (AMLC) said on Thursday.
David Palmer, manager food safety and quality assurance at AMLC, told Reuters that exports of meat from the affected area were normally "minuscule".
The ceasing of exports from the area would have little effect on trade, he said.
Palmer was commenting on a statement by South Korea's Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry that it had asked Australia to halt beef exports from areas hit by anthrax.
No slaughtering of cattle in the area for human consumption had taken place since the discovery of the outbreak, he said.
"Nothing from that area has entered the human food chain," he said.
This was a normal result of the quarantine measures which had been imposed, he said.
The anthrax-affected zone, mainly a dairy farming district, is only 15 km by three km in area.

On Thursday afternoon, the number of properties confirmed with anthrax stood at 71, while 138 cattle and one sheep had been confirmed dead from anthrax, the Department of Natural Resources and Environment said.
A total of 32,700 cattle and 900 sheep had been vaccinated, it said.
Anthrax is a bacterial disease which causes rapid death in cattle and sheep but is rarely contracted by humans.
Dairy products, including processed export products, are safe for human consumption, Australian authorities have repeatedly stated.
